description.narrative: Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida): Programme Area A (Biodiversity).

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
1.1 Number of local nature-based solutions identified through this project, including count of number of solutions that are women’s groups or women-led 1.2 Number of national and global events in which local solutions are featured 1.3 Number of case studies, best practices, learning materials on nature-based solutions created, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences in benefiting from sustainable development outcomes 1.4 Number of people, including policy makers, reached through webinars, e-learning, open online courses and through local-national dialogues, and through social media, disaggregated by sex 1.5: Number of solutions adopted and replicated as a result of this program

1.1 Number of local nature-based solutions identified through this project, including count of number of solutions that are women’s groups or women-led: 1000 1.2 Number of national and global events in which local solutions are featured: 15 1.3 Number of case studies, best practices, learning materials on nature-based solutions created, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences in benefiting from sustainable development outcomes: 35 1.4 Number of people, including policy makers, reached through webinars, e-learning, open online courses and through local-national dialogues, and through social media, disaggregated by sex: 2000 1.5: Number of solutions adopted and replicated as a result of this program: 20
2.1 Number of solutions developed and uploaded onto solutions portal, including from the UNDP GEF portfolio, including count of number of solutions that are targeted to women and advance gender equality: 250 2.2 Number of countries accessing and using solutions and spatial planning portals: 50 2.3 Number of people accessing learning materials, including webinars, online courses, disaggregated by sex: 1500 2.4 Number of actions taken by countries that have direct and measurable impacts on SDGs, as measured by SDG targets and indicators: 30
3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced: 6 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals: 400 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate: 25 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants: 200 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis: 3 major meetings

1.1 Number of local nature-based solutions identified through this project, including count of number of solutions that are women’s groups or women-led: RESULT: 600 – 600 nominations identified through Equator Prize 2021 selection process. 1.2 Number of national and global events in which local solutions are featured: RESULT: 57 – 1 Equator Prize global ceremony, 4 Equator Prize national ceremonies, 15 events in which Equator Prize winners were featured, 37 events related to UN Biodiversity Lab/Essential Life Support Areas/spatial tools for development planning 1.3 Number of case studies, best practices, learning materials on nature-based solutions created, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences in benefiting from sustainable development outcomes: RESULT: 142 – 21 Equator Prize winner case studies published, 9 photo stories and blogs, 4 press releases; 21 knowledge products out of Learning for Nature (4 podcasts, 9 impact stories, 8 Google Earth stories featuring 56 Equator Prize winners); 100 knowledge products out of our work on spatial tools for development planning (UNBL/ELSA) 1.4 Number of people, including policy makers, reached through webinars, e-learning, open online courses and through local-national dialogues, and through social media, disaggregated by sex: RESULT: approx. 63,000 -- 37,792 users in the Learning for Nature community; 24,000 viewers of the Equator Prize 2021 award ceremony; approx. 900 individuals reached by ELSA workshops; approx. 400 million impressions through Nature for Life Hub (not included in count) 1.5: Number of solutions adopted and replicated as a result of this program: RESULT: 13 – 10 (Equator Prize money disbursed); 3 (NASA Life on Land)
2.1 Number of solutions developed and uploaded onto solutions portal, including from the UNDP GEF portfolio, including count of number of solutions that are targeted to women and advance gender equality: RESULT: 1,001 – Learning for Nature: 98 solutions developed (Gender and Mining: 4 lessons in French, 4 lessons in Spanish; Multidimensional Poverty Index 2.0: 5 lessons in French, 5 in Spanish; UNDP Green Bonds Training: 16 lessons for self-paced version in 3 languages, 6 case studies in 3 languages each, 6 presentations for live trainings in 3 languages each, Project Access Online 14 video lectures in 4 languages); work supporting Convention on Biological Diversity: 197 Aichi Biodiversity Target 11 (ABT-11) Country Dossiers developed, which include a status of ABT-11 elements and opportunities for action informed by spatial maps; 181 of these ABT-11 Country Dossiers have been uploaded to the CBD Protected Areas website for national and public use, following national approval for posting; work on spatial tools for development planning: 51 2.2 Number of countries accessing and using solutions and spatial planning portals: RESULT: 188 – work supporting CBD: 79 countries have reviewed and provided feedback on the ABT-11 Country Dossiers; work on spatial tools for development planning: 188 countries engaged 2.3 Number of people accessing learning materials, including webinars, online courses, disaggregated by sex: RESULT: 14,299 – Learning for Nature: 8,690 non-unique enrollees in Learning for Nature offerings in 2021; work on spatial tools for development planning: 5,579 – interactions in NBSAP forum; 30 – NASA Life on Land roundtables 2.4 Number of actions taken by countries that have direct and measurable impacts on SDGs, as measured by SDG targets and indicators: RESULT: 10 – 3 NASA Life on Land; 7 new ELSA countries
3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced: RESULT: 29 – NYDF: 5 (NYDF Refresh launch at Global Landscapes Forum, Deforestation-free Commodities event at ISAF Japan, NYDF Commitments to Action event during UNFCCC COP26 at Global Landscapes Forum, 2 Forest Solutions Dialogues); work on spatial tools for development planning: 24 (17 ELSA workshops, 7 NASA roundtables) 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals: RESULT: 219 endorsers total (24 new NYDF endorsers have been added since the start of the project). Additionally, COP26 was a pivotal moment for forest commitments where many public and private sector commitments aligned with the NYDF goal of halting deforestation by 2030 were made including, 141 countries committing to the Glasgow Leaders Declaration on Forests and Land Use, 12 companies committed to the Agricultural Commodity Corporate Statement of Purpose, and 30 financial institutions committed to eliminating investments in agricultural commodity-driven deforestation. 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate: RESULT: 10 – NYDF: 8 (2 NBS in NDC country briefings; 3 NYDF Assessment reports and publications; 1 Revised NYDF Declaration with updated preamble and goals; 2 new blogs to discuss new restoration data and the outcomes of COP26); work on spatial tools for development planning: 1 (Letter Towards monitoring forest ecosystem integrity within the Post-2020 biodiversity framework); work supporting the CBD: 1 (the Creating a Nature-Positive Future Global Report and the 197 ABT-11 Country Dossiers are key knowledge products for Parties of the Convention on Biological Diversity to enhance the quantity and quality of protected and conserved areas to achieve biodiversity as well as climate change and sustainable development priorities: 1 global report, 197 Country Dossiers) 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants: RESULT: 143 – NYDF: 33 Indigenous Peoples and local communities (6 M, 1 F participated in NYDF Refresh working group and consultations calls and consultations; 1 M + 1 F panelists at NYDF Refresh virtual launch event, October 2021; 1 F panelist at NYDF event during UNFCC COP26 at Global Landscapes Forum, November 2021; 12 F + 11 M in 2 meetings with the Global Alliance for Territorial Communities to consult on the NYDF Refresh and IPLC Action Plan); work on spatial tools for development planning: 10 IPLC representatives in ELSA workshops for Peru and Ecuador; Equator Initiative: 100 in various events 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis: RESULT: 1 major meeting (UNFCCC COP26). The NYDF Platform played a leading role, through engagement with the UK COP26 team, in ensuring that forests and nature was one of the pillars of the COP26 Presidency, and in setting the ambition and shaping the narrative for a World Leaders Summit event on forests and land use. Additionally, leading up to COP26 and to prepare for the NYDF Refresh launch event in October 2021, the NYDF Platform organized 9 group consultation sessions with the NYDF refresh working group and 30 bilateral meetings with members of the NYDF community (including governments, private sector, Indigenous Peoples, and donors) to collect feedback and inputs on the NYDF Goals and role of the Platform, resulting in a revised set of forest goals and increased endorser engagement ahead of COP26.

1.1 Number of local nature-based solutions identified through this project, including count of number of solutions that are women’s groups or women-led: 1000 1.2 Number of national and global events in which local solutions are featured: 10 1.3 Number of case studies, best practices, learning materials on nature-based solutions created, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences in benefiting from sustainable development outcomes: 25 1.4 Number of people, including policy makers, reached through webinars, e-learning, open online courses and through local-national dialogues, and through social media, disaggregated by sex: 1500 1.5: Number of solutions adopted and replicated as a result of this program: 20

3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced: 6 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals: 300 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate: 25 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants: 100 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis: 3 major meetings

1.1 Number of local nature-based solutions identified through this project, including count of number of solutions that are women’s groups or women-led: Result: 583 -- 583 solutions identified through the Equator Prize 2020 nomination process 1.2 Number of national and global events in which local solutions are featured. RESULT: 34 -- 5 Equator Prize national ceremonies held, 8 policy events in which 12 Equator Prize winners were represented, Held Equator Prize 2020 Ceremony virtually, 10 events at Nature for Life Hub that featured local solutions 1.3 Number of case studies, best practices, learning materials on nature-based solutions created, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences in benefiting from sustainable development outcomes: Result: 77 -- 21 new Equator Prize case studies published in 2020, 11 mini-documentaries about Equator Prize 2020 winners produced, and one community statement, 11 social media short videos produced about Equator Prize 2020 winners, 8 photo stories and blogs produced, 10 podcasts produced, 11 Google Earth stories produced, 5 thematic issues with relevance to local actors covered on Learning for Nature 1.4 Number of people, including policy makers, reached through webinars, e-learning, open online courses and through local-national dialogues, and through social media, disaggregated by sex. Result: 75,054 -- Approx. 50,000 people reached through national ceremonies and involvement of Equator Prize winners in policy events, 25,054 individuals reached on LfN, 27.1 million impressions related to the Equator Prize award ceremony 1.5: Number of solutions adopted and replicated as a result of this program: Unknown.
More info: https://www.dropbox.com/s/7y4jqdgyjjuboyk/2020%20annual%20report%20NfD%20clean.pdf?dl=0
2.1 Number of solutions developed and uploaded onto solutions portal, including from the UNDP GEF portfolio, including count of number of solutions that are targeted to women and advance gender equality. Result: 655 - Created UNDP Open Planet database and uploaded information for 655 projects 2.2 Number of countries accessing and using solutions and spatial planning portals. Results: 64 -- 64 countries supported to use spatial data in their NBSAP reporting 2.3 Number of people accessing learning materials, including webinars, online courses, disaggregated by sex. Result: 25,054 individuals reached on Learning for Nature platform, Provided in-person technical support to over 800 stakeholders during 142 global workshops and four help desks and on the margins of CBD events, and at or eight regional workshops. Over 1,500 entities additionally also participated in live webinars, for which online recordings viewed over 6,350 times 2.4 Number of actions taken by countries that have direct and measurable impacts on SDGs, as measured by SDG targets and indicators. Result: 38 -- 33 countries submitted 6th National Reports that were gender-responsive, Initiated or completed process of identification of ‘Essential Life Support Areas’ (ELSAs) in 5 countries
More info: https://www.dropbox.com/s/7y4jqdgyjjuboyk/2020%20annual%20report%20NfD%20clean.pdf?dl=0
3.1 Number of events at which the NYDF, and related forest issues, is advanced. Result: over 15 -- Involved at 5 major NYDF events (Global Landscapes Forum, several virtual engagements – see report), 10+ events at Nature for Life Hub 3.2 Number of signatories of governments, companies and communities who have demonstrated commitment and who have undertaken concrete steps to achieve one or more of the NYDF goals. Result: Approx. 200 (12 new endorsers) 3.3 Number of knowledge management products and solutions produced on sustainable forestry, deforestation-free commodities and reforestation, among other NYDF-related themes, including reflections on contributions by women and women’s groups and/or gender-specific differences, where appropriate. Result: 39 -- Equator Initiative case studies: 21, Equator Initiative photo essays: 8, NYDF: 10 blogs 3.4 Number of indigenous peoples and local communities engaged in forest-related global events, advocating for a land rights, forest protection, disaggregated by sex of participants. Result: 70 -- Approx. 30 IPLC representatives represented at NYDF events, 40 IPLC individuals engaged in Equator Prize 2020, 20 of which were women 3.5 Number of knowledge products, events, calls, workshops and meetings to support Convention Secretariats, on a demand-driven basis. Result: 4 -- NYDF: Global Landscapes Forum, Finance for Nature Series (2), 1 major meeting on spatial planning
More info: https://www.dropbox.com/s/7y4jqdgyjjuboyk/2020%20annual%20report%20NfD%20clean.pdf?dl=0
